  • Seer ended 2025 with $241 million in cash, cash equivalents, and investments. Free cash flow loss for 2025 was $45.6 million, with expectations to reduce this loss in 2026.
  • The Board adopted a tax benefit preservation plan to protect $262 million in net operating loss carryforwards.

Q&A

  • Kyle Boucher, TD Cowen, asked about the Q4 revenue shortfall and whether delays impacted results. Horn answered, "there was some NIH funding around some projects that got delayed that was supposed to be paid in '25 and didn't, got pushed into this year."
  • Boucher inquired about the rationale for 2026 guidance given recent momentum. Farokhzad said, "the guide may seem conservative. I think the challenge we have is that until I see a very clear momentum, we want to be guarded in the way we see our revenue projections." Horn added, "the guide does assume we kind of have a difficult NIH environment remaining as far as we can see."
  • Boucher asked about barriers to adoption beyond funding. Farokhzad responded that "the data that's coming from the customers is reflected on the publications that are coming. The biological insight that comes when you do untargeted proteomics at scale is profound." He underscored the need for more evidence and publications to drive wider adoption.

Sentiment Analysis

  • Analysts pressed management on revenue shortfalls, guidance conservatism, and adoption barriers, maintaining a neutral to slightly negative tone as they probed reasons for slower growth and future visibility.
  • Management conveyed confidence in long-term opportunity but acknowledged near-term challenges, with Farokhzad stating "the tailwind is getting stronger and stronger, despite the ongoing headwind of the macro picture." The tone was measured, particularly when discussing guidance and customer adoption.
  • Compared to the previous quarter, analyst tone shifted from cautious optimism to more pointed concerns about growth trajectory, while management’s outlook became more conservative, emphasizing prudence and evidence-based forecasting.

Quarter-over-Quarter Comparison

  • Revenue growth slowed, with Q4 2025 revenue at $4.2 million compared to $4.1 million in Q3, and annual guidance for 2026 ($16 million to $18 million) below the prior full-year target.
  • Installed base growth and consumable volumes remained strong, but management’s tone around guidance shifted from expecting strong growth to emphasizing caution due to persistent NIH funding uncertainties.
  • Analysts in both quarters focused on instrument placements, large-scale study opportunities, and funding headwinds, but current questions revealed heightened concern over whether recent momentum can sustain higher growth.
  • Management reiterated commitment to innovation and highlighted a new search for a Chief Commercial Officer as a forthcoming organizational change.

Risks and Concerns

  • Persistent uncertainty around NIH and government funding remains a key challenge, directly impacting customer purchasing decisions and timing of orders.
  • Management’s mitigation strategies include expanding volume-based pricing, strategic programs like SIPP and STAC to lower adoption barriers, and a new tax benefit preservation plan.
  • Analyst concerns centered on the lumpy nature of quarterly results, conservatism in guidance, and the need for more widespread customer adoption to drive sustained growth.

Final Takeaway

Seer’s management highlighted solid progress in expanding its installed base, advancing product innovation, and maintaining a strong cash position, but emphasized caution in revenue guidance for 2026 amid ongoing NIH funding uncertainties and elongated sales cycles. The company is investing in next-generation technology and has expanded its share repurchase program, while continuing to focus on lowering adoption barriers and capturing new market opportunities as customer evidence and validation build. Investors are closely watching for concrete signs that accelerating scientific adoption and product validation will translate into sustained and material revenue growth.
